t: Job 3
Job’s Lament
Afterward*p Job opened his mouth and cursed the day of his birth.*i
And Job said,
“Let*pn the day perish on which I was to be born, And*ln the night which*i said, ‘A boy is conceived.’
May*ln that day be darkness; Let*ln not God above care for it, Nor*ln light shine on it.
Let*ln darkness and black gloom claim it; Let*ln a cloud settle on it; Let*ln the blackness of the day terrify it.
As*iln for*i that night, let darkness seize it; Let*ln it not rejoice among the days of the year; Let*ln it not come into the number of the months.
Behold,*ln let that night be barren; Let*ln no joyful shout enter it.
Let*ln those curse it who curse the day, Who*ln are prepared to rouse Leviathan.
Let*ln the stars of its twilight be darkened; Let*ln it wait for light but have none, And*ln let it not see the breaking dawn;
Because*ln it did not shut the opening of my mother’s*i womb, Or*ln hide trouble from my eyes.
“Why*ln did I not die at birth, Come*ln forth from the womb and expire?
Why*ln did the knees receive me, And*ln why the breasts, that I should suck?
For*ln now I would have lain down and been quiet; I*ln would have slept then, I would have been at rest,
With*ln kings and with*i counselors of the earth, Who*ln rebuilt ruins for themselves;
Or*ln with princes who had gold, Who*ln were filling their houses with*i silver.
Or*ln like a miscarriage which is discarded, I would not be, As*ln infants that never saw light.
There*ln the wicked cease from raging, And*ln there the weary are at rest.
The*ln prisoners are at ease together; They*ln do not hear the voice of the taskmaster.
The*ln small and the great are there, And*ln the slave is free from his master.
“Why*ln is light given to him who suffers, And*ln life to the bitter of soul,
Who*ln long for death, but there is none, And*ln dig for it more than for hidden treasures,
Who*ln rejoice greatly, And*iln exult when they find the grave?
Why*iln is*i light*i given*i to a man whose way is hidden, And*ln whom God has hedged in?
For*ln my groaning comes at the sight of my food, And*ln my cries pour out like water.
For*ln what I fear comes upon me, And*ln what I dread befalls me.
I*ln am not at ease, nor am I quiet, And*ln I am not at rest, but turmoil comes.”
